text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on May 25 in history:
1787 - A convention under George Washington met for the first time to draw up the new U.S. constitution.
1803 - Ralph Waldo Emerson, American poet, essayist and leading exponent of New England Transcendentalism, born.
1810 - A revolution began in Rio de la Plata (later Argentina), when an autonomous government was set up in Buenos Aires.
1826 - Tom Sayers, bare-knuckled English pugilist who once took part in a 42-round fight over two hours, born.
1879 - Lord Beaverbrook, English statesman and newspaper owner, born as William Maxwell Aitken. He was a cabinet minister in both World Wars and owned the Daily and Sunday Express newspapers.
1889 - Igor Sikorsky, Russian-born aeronautical engineer and inventor of the helicopter, born.
1895 - Writer Oscar Wilde was sentenced to two years hard labour in Britain for being a sodomite.
1897 - Gene Tunney, American heavyweight boxing champion, born as James Joseph Tunney.
1911 - President Porfirio Diaz resigned after revolutionist forces defeated government troops in the Mexican Civil War.
1915 - In Europe, the second Battle of Ypres ended with casualties around 105,000. The Germans used poison gas for the first time.
1923 - Britain recognised the country of Transjordan with Abdullah as its leader; On this day in 1946 a new treaty recognised it as a sovereign state called Jordan with Abdullah as King.
1926 - Miles Davis, U.S. jazz trumpeter and composer, born.
1929 - Beverley Sills, U.S. operatic soprano renowned for her role in "La Traviata", born.
1934 - Gustav Holst, English composer notably of the suite "The Planets", died.
1935 - American athlete Jesse Owens set six world records in 45 minutes.
1951 - Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean, British foreign office officials, disappeared from London. It was later discovered they had spied for Russia.
1963 - A summit conference of African states ended in Addis Ababa with agreement to set up the Organisation of African Unity.
1969 - The Sudanese government was overthrown in a military coup led by Col. Jaafar Nimeiri.
1979 - America's worst-ever air disaster occurred when a DC-10 crashed at Chicago's O'Hare airport killing 273.
1983 - A fire on board three vessels on a trip on the Upper Nile in Egypt killed over 300 people.
1986 - 30 million people worldwide joined in Bob Geldof's "Race Against Time" to raise money for the starving in Africa.
1989 - Mikhail Gorbachev was elected to the new post of Executive President in the Soviet Union.
1990 - Winnie Mandela's chief bodyguard, Jerry Richardson, was found guilty of the murder of 14-year-old Stompie Seipei.
1991 - 15,000 Falashas - Ethiopia Jews - were airlifted from Addis Ababa to Israel as rebel forces approached the Ethiopian capital.
1992 - Veteran Italian politician Oscar Luigi Scalfaro was elected President.
1993 - Guatemalan President Jorge Serrano dissolved congress and suspended the constitution amid fears of a coup.
1994 - Russian writer Alexander Solzhenitsyn, ending a 20-year exile in the West, left his home in Cavendish, Vermont to begin his long journey back to Russia.
1995 - A major flare-up in the Bosnian war began when NATO launched air strikes against ammunition bunkers near Pale.
1996 - Bulgaria's King Simeon II came home after 50 years of exile to a rapturous welcome from royalist crowds and a cold-shoulder from the socialist government.
